MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

Services

Kalamazoo, MI 49001-6170

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section (1) An agency shall develop a plan of visitation and family time for
Description each child in foster care consistent with the child's service plans,
as required by R 400.12419 and R 400.12420 to ensure the safety
and well-being of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation Parents residing out of state have not been offered parenting time
since case management transitioned from one worker to another a
month ago.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Care Program Manager
On 11/20/2024 I spoke with Foster Care Program Manager
(FCPM) by telephone about his complaint. FCPM affirmed the
agency has the case this complaint relates to. He reported the
worker who originally had the case, Foster Care Worker (FCW) 1
went on leave of absence on 10/28/2024; and did not ask for case
coverage which may have impacted the continued timeliness of
the parenting visitation schedule. He reported the case was
transferred to FCW 2, and another supervisor, Foster Care
Supervisor (FCS) 2 effective 10/28/2024. He said Monday and
Tuesday at 5:30m were the days parent/child visitation were to
occur. He said a visit occurred on Monday 10/28/2024. He
reported given FCW 1’s departure and FCW 2 trying to work out
scheduling and to coordinate the visits, there may have been a
couple of weeks where there was no visit. He reported the
children are in two different foster homes and that too may have
impacted scheduling. She reported FCW 2, and FCS 2 would
have more specifics related to the parent/child visitation situation.
Additionally, the prior foster care supervisor, FCS 1, may be able
to speak to what FCW 1 had done related to parent/child visits.
2

Parent A
On 12/2/2023 I interviewed Parent A about this complaint. He
expressed concern that his children were removed from his care
by children services for a false and erroneous reasons. He
reported in the past the court had ordered there to be two visits
per month for he and his wife, Parent B, with their children, twin
boys, Child C, and Child D, and daughter Child E. He reported his
boys are placed in one foster home and his daughter in another
foster home. He reported after his case transferred from FCW 1
to FCW 2 there was a month without a visit. He reported he and
his wife live out of state; and although he knows FCW 2 “came to
a messed-up case” that FCW 1 left without notice and her leaving
impacted on their visitation schedule, his concern is why is the
agency not calling him. Why is he not getting his parenting time
and getting it when he is available. He said FCW 2 is trying to
arrange some visits, but they put all the children on at the same
time, and there has only been one visit since 11/18/2024, which
was on 11/25/2024. He said the FCW 2 said she was trying to
arrange visits for Mondays when he is off; and also Wednesday;
but he works on that day. He is free up to 5:00PM on Wednedays
and also free any other weekday. He said he just wanted his
children back and is awaiting on ICPC (Interstate Compact on the
Placement of Children) to assess he and Parent B; but in the
meantime, he just wants to see his children and wants the workers
to call him. He is concerned the department is trying to keep his
children.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) 2
On 12/10/2024 I interviewed FCS 2 by telephone. FCS 2 affirmed
she and FCW 2 received responsibility for Child C, Child D, and
Child E’s cases on 10/28/2024, after FCW 1 left without notice.
FCS 2 reported after the case transferred to FCW 2, FCW 2
began trying to make contacts with Parent A and Parent B that
day. FCS 2 reported the parents were consistently difficult to get
a hold of due to their telephone being turned off or different issues
with their email which the parents were apparently communicating
through. Parent B’s email was incorrect; they only had Parent A’s
email, at first, and they were initially sending emails to this email
without success.
FCS 2 reported the agency has offered parenting visits to the
parents. She said, FCW 2 set the parent/child visitation for
Mondays and Wednesdays, as Tuesdays could not be
accommodated by FCW 2’s work schedule and is not constantly
feasible for the two different care providers. FCS 2 reported
3

Parent A and Parent B reside in Missouri and parenting times are
via TEAMS. She reported the visitation was set with FCW 2
supervising the parent/child visitation via TEAMS on Wednesday
and a social service aide supervising the Monday visitations.
FCS 2 said they set up a calendar invite, and they were sending
that to the parents via text and Parent A’s email. She said a
parenting time would have fallen on 11/11/2024, a state holiday,
so they offered a makeup visit on 11/12/2024. FCS 2 said the
agency’s contacts were not all being responded to by Parent A.
FCS 2 reported sometime in November 2024 they learned Parent
A had apparently gotten some of the contacts from them but had
not contacted the worker. Parent A had apparently also contacted
his attorney about what he thought was a lack of contacts to him;
and the attorney contacted the agency. FCS 2 said they apprised
the attorney of their outreach to Parent A and Parent B, and the
attorney indicated he would let Parent A, know. FCS 2 said Parent
A and Parent B finally contacted the agency on or about
11/14/2024; which was also when she got more involved. She
sent an email to Parent A on 11/21/2024 related to a parenting
visit and obtaining Parent B’s email to send Parent B the link so
they could get on the parent/child visit. FCS 2 said she sent the
link to Parent B twice by text and email. She said the parents were
able to visit on 11/18/2024 and 11/25/2024; everyone was on the
TEAMs visit. Two other scheduled visits, which were on
Wednesdays (11/20/2024 and 11/27/2024) were not successful,
because either the caregiver or parents did not get on the visit.
FCS 2 said there have been visits set but unfortunately due to the
parents not responding to the TEAMS link or not logging on only
two visits have been successful. She reported the latter could
have also been due to the family having a problem with their Wi-
Fi. The agency learned Parent B’s phone was only working on Wi-
Fi (it was not known if the family had other Wi-Fi in the home).
FCS 2 reported the family has since indicated they are getting
their phones back on tomorrow, 12/11/2024; which should help
them with successfully connecting to the visits. She said another
visit is set for 12/11/2024 and everyone is set for that visit. FCS
admitted there was an issue with the Wednesdays 5:30PM
parenting time for Parent A, in that Tuesday is what Parent A,
wanted because with Wednesday, he could only be on for a half
hour due to needing to leave for work. She reported the case is
being transferred from her and FCW 2 to FCW 3 and another
supervisor this week; and this should help with scheduling. She
said Parent A and Parent B have been apprised of this change.
FCS also reported, the children’s case plan remains reunification
4

and the ICPC is being sent this week for the out of state home
study on Parent A and Parent B.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS)1
On 12/18/2024 I interviewed FCS 1 by telephone. She affirmed
being the supervisor for the prior worker, FCW 1 and FCW 1’s
departure from the case. She affirmed Parent A and Parent B’s
parenting time was occurring virtually on Mondays and Tuesdays.
She said FCW 1 was sending out emails to the parent for those
visits. She reported the parents often had problems logging on or
couldn’t find the parenting time visitation link. She reported the
parents never complained about missed parenting visits. What
they consistently complained about was children services and
their belief the children should not have been removed from them.
She reported any time parenting visits were missed it was due to
the parents. They either could not figure out how to log on to the
parenting visit or they did not log on. FCS 1 reported the parents
issues were substance abuse related; she was not aware of the
parents having cognitive delays that may have caused their
difficulty logging on to any of the virtual parenting times.
FCS 1 reported after the case transferred to FCW 2’s and FCS 2’s
supervision, Parent A’s attorney reached out to her via email
around Veteran day; and she followed up with him on or about
11/14/2024. The attorney indicated Parent A was saying FCW 1
was no longer his worker, and he had not had a visit since FCW 1
left. She provided the attorney FCW 2, And FCS 2’s name and
contact information. She said Parent A had also reached out to
her on 11/11/2024, when the agency was closed, and she
contacted him back with FCW 2 and FCS 2’s information as well.
FCS 1 was not sure how many visits had been scheduled with
Parent A and Parent B, but the parents lack of consistency in
keeping parenting times had been discussed in past meeting.
She was also not aware of efforts FCW 2, and FCS 2 had made
with the parents after she provided their contact information to the
parents.
Foster Care Worker 2
On 1/3/2025, I interviewed FCW 2 by telephone. FCW 2 affirmed
information as reported by FCS 2 related to FCW 1’s departure,
their efforts in trying to contact the parents and the parents
technology issues and difficulties. FCS 2 said she set the parent/
child visits for Mondays and Wednesdays. She said the parents
were initially okay with the change of parenting time from Tuesday
to Wednesday. Parent A later voiced a concern of Wednesdays
5

not being good for him, because he could only attend for the
beginning of the visit. He would have to leave for work. The
Wednesday time worked for the caregivers and Parent B. FCW 2
reported given that the agency was closed one Monday in
November 2024 and the holiday in November the time gap that
existed after FCW 1’s departure and her taking over the case was
about two weeks. She reported visits she supervised were for
11/18/2024, 11/25/2024, 12/2/2024(which the parents missed due
to technology issues). She said a visit was also set for
12/12/2024, but she did not supervise that one, because the case
had transferred to FCW 3. She reported the delay in scheduling
visits was due to barriers outside her control, not due to a lack of
her trying to connect to the parents and to set the parent/child
visits in November 2024.
Documentation Review
Copy of emails or text messages
• Copy of a 11/12/2024 email from FCS 1 to Parent A
advising him of FCW 1’s departure without notice on
10/28/2024, and the agency had been trying to figure out
what FCW 1 had or had not completed since that time.
Also, that FCW 2 and FCS 2 have been assigned to his
case, are aware that parenting time needs to be set up
virtually, and the ICPC request completed.
• Copy of text messages from FCS 2 showing various
contacts to Parent A and Parent B, and some replies from
the parents. Various texts showed the parenting link was
attached; or that the agency or the parents were asked
about problems contacting the other. The messages
conveyed that the agency was not able to connect with
them and asked the parents if the agency had the wrong
contact information.
MISACWIS case record for Child C, Child D and Child E, which
showed:
• Child C, Child D and Child E were last made temporary
court wards on 12/18/2023. This was the third time Child C
and Child D were made temporary court wards; and the
second time for Child E.
• Parenting time visits after a parenting time visit on
10/28/2024 were set for 11/11/2024 (which could not occur
as the agency was closed for Veteran day- the parents
were offered a makeup), 11/18/2024; 11/25/2024,
12/2/2024 (which did not occur because the parents never
logged on); 12/9/2024 (the visit was cancelled because
neither the parents nor the caregivers confirmed for the
6

visit); 12/11/2024, 12/16/2024, 12/19/2024; 12/23/2024;
and 12/30/2024 (all of which occurred with the parents; with
all the children attending).
• A 11/20/2024 and 11/21/2024 text message from FCS 2 to
Child C’s and Child D’s caregiver reminding the caregiver
of a parenting time that was occurring for the former, and of
a upcoming visit that day for the latter. This caregiver’s
participation was encouraged.
• Emails and or texts messages to Parent B and or Parent A
from FCS 2 and FCW 2 about visitation.
• A copy of a 12/9/2024 ICPC for a home study request to
the state of Missouri completed by FCW 2.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence does
not show that the agency deliberately and purposely delayed
parenting time for the parents after FCW 1 left the agency. Nor
that the agency did not develop a parenting time plan for the
children’s family. The agency was trying to maintain contact with
the parents after FCW 1’s departure, and they continued to
schedule parenting time visits.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Continuation of the agency’s current licensing status is recommended.
February 10, 2025
